trans-unit.source: Step 3: Create a new Machine Learning experiment | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Create a new Machine Learning experiment | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Step 3 of the Develop a predictive solution walkthrough: Create a new training experiment in Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: Step 3 of the Develop a predictive solution walkthrough: Create a new training experiment in Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: This is the third step of the walkthrough, <linkText>Developing a Predictive Solution with Azure ML</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: This is the third step of the walkthrough, <linkText>Developing a Predictive Solution with Azure ML</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a Machine Learning workspace</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a Machine Learning workspace</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Upload existing data</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Upload existing data</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Create a new experiment
trans-unit.target: Create a new experiment

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Train and evaluate the models</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Train and evaluate the models</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish the web service</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish the web service</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Access the web service</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Access the web service</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: We need to create a new experiment in ML Studio that uses the dataset we uploaded.
trans-unit.target: We need to create a new experiment in ML Studio that uses the dataset we uploaded.

trans-unit.source: In ML Studio, click +NEW at the bottom of the window.
trans-unit.target: In ML Studio, click +NEW at the bottom of the window.

trans-unit.source: Select EXPERIMENT, and then select "Blank Experiment".
trans-unit.target: Select EXPERIMENT, and then select "Blank Experiment".

trans-unit.source: Select the default experiment name at the top of the canvas and rename it to something meaningful
trans-unit.target: Select the default experiment name at the top of the canvas and rename it to something meaningful

trans-unit.source: It's a good practice to fill in Summary and Description for the experiment in the Properties pane.
trans-unit.target: It's a good practice to fill in Summary and Description for the experiment in the Properties pane.

trans-unit.source: These properties give you the chance to document the experiment so that anyone who looks at it later will understand your goals and methodology.
trans-unit.target: These properties give you the chance to document the experiment so that anyone who looks at it later will understand your goals and methodology.

trans-unit.source: In the module palette to the left of the experiment canvas, expand Saved Datasets.
trans-unit.target: In the module palette to the left of the experiment canvas, expand Saved Datasets.

trans-unit.source: Find the dataset you created under My Datasets and drag it onto the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Find the dataset you created under My Datasets and drag it onto the canvas.

trans-unit.source: You can also find the dataset by entering the name in the Search box above the palette.
trans-unit.target: You can also find the dataset by entering the name in the Search box above the palette.

trans-unit.source: You can view the first 100 rows of the data and some statistical information for the whole dataset by clicking the output port of the dataset and selecting View Results.
trans-unit.target: You can view the first 100 rows of the data and some statistical information for the whole dataset by clicking the output port of the dataset and selecting View Results.

trans-unit.source: Notice that ML Studio has already identified the data type for each column.
trans-unit.target: Notice that ML Studio has already identified the data type for each column.

trans-unit.source: It has also given generic headings to the columns because the data file did not come with column headings.
trans-unit.target: It has also given generic headings to the columns because the data file did not come with column headings.

trans-unit.source: Column headings are not essential, but they will make it easier to work with the data in the model.
trans-unit.target: Column headings are not essential, but they will make it easier to work with the data in the model.

trans-unit.source: Also, when we eventually publish this model in a web service, the headings will help identify the columns to the user of the service.
trans-unit.target: Also, when we eventually publish this model in a web service, the headings will help identify the columns to the user of the service.

trans-unit.source: We can add column headings using the <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> module.
trans-unit.target: We can add column headings using the <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> module.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> module is used to change the metadata associated with a dataset.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> module is used to change the metadata associated with a dataset.

trans-unit.source: In this case, it can provide more friendly names for column headings.
trans-unit.target: In this case, it can provide more friendly names for column headings.

trans-unit.source: To do this, we'll direct <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> to act on all columns and then provide a list of names to be added to the columns.
trans-unit.target: To do this, we'll direct <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> to act on all columns and then provide a list of names to be added to the columns.

trans-unit.source: In the module palette, type "metadata" in the Search box.
trans-unit.target: In the module palette, type "metadata" in the Search box.

trans-unit.source: You'll see <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> in the module list.
trans-unit.target: You'll see <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> in the module list.

trans-unit.source: Click and drag the <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> module onto the canvas and drop it below the dataset.
trans-unit.target: Click and drag the <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> module onto the canvas and drop it below the dataset.

trans-unit.source: Connect the dataset to the <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title>: click the output port of the dataset, drag to the input port of <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title>, then release the mouse button.
trans-unit.target: Connect the dataset to the <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title>: click the output port of the dataset, drag to the input port of <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title>, then release the mouse button.

trans-unit.source: The dataset and module will remain connected even if you move either around on the canvas.
trans-unit.target: The dataset and module will remain connected even if you move either around on the canvas.

trans-unit.source: With the Metadata Editor[metadata-editor] still selected, in the Properties pane to the right of the canvas, click Launch column selector.
trans-unit.target: With the Metadata Editor[metadata-editor] still selected, in the Properties pane to the right of the canvas, click Launch column selector.

trans-unit.source: In the Select columns dialog, set the Begin With field to "All columns".
trans-unit.target: In the Select columns dialog, set the Begin With field to "All columns".

trans-unit.source: The row beneath Begin With allows you to include or exclude specific columns for the Metadata Editor[metadata-editor] to modify.
trans-unit.target: The row beneath Begin With allows you to include or exclude specific columns for the Metadata Editor[metadata-editor] to modify.

trans-unit.source: Since we want to modify all columns, delete this row by clicking the minus sign ("-") to the right of the row.
trans-unit.target: Since we want to modify all columns, delete this row by clicking the minus sign ("-") to the right of the row.

trans-unit.source: The dialog should look like this: <linkText>Column Selector with all columns selected</linkText>
trans-unit.target: The dialog should look like this: <linkText>Column Selector with all columns selected</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the OK checkmark.
trans-unit.target: Click the OK checkmark.

trans-unit.source: Back in the Properties pane, look for the New column names parameter.
trans-unit.target: Back in the Properties pane, look for the New column names parameter.

trans-unit.source: In this field, enter a list of names for the 21 columns in the dataset, separated by commas and in column order.
trans-unit.target: In this field, enter a list of names for the 21 columns in the dataset, separated by commas and in column order.

trans-unit.source: You can obtain the columns names from the dataset documentation on the UCI website, or for convenience you can copy and paste the following:
trans-unit.target: You can obtain the columns names from the dataset documentation on the UCI website, or for convenience you can copy and paste the following:

trans-unit.source: status of checking account, duration in months, credit history, purpose, credit amount, savings account/bond, present employment since, installment rate in percentage of disposable income, personal status and sex, other debtors, present residence since, property, age in years, other installment plans, housing, number of existing credits, job, number of people providing maintenance for, telephone, foreign worker, credit risk
trans-unit.target: status of checking account, duration in months, credit history, purpose, credit amount, savings account/bond, present employment since, installment rate in percentage of disposable income, personal status and sex, other debtors, present residence since, property, age in years, other installment plans, housing, number of existing credits, job, number of people providing maintenance for, telephone, foreign worker, credit risk

trans-unit.source: The Properties pane will look like this:
trans-unit.target: The Properties pane will look like this:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Properties for Metadata Editor</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Properties for Metadata Editor</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you want to verify the column headings, run the experiment (click RUN below the experiment canvas), click the output port of the Metadata Editor[metadata-editor] module, and select View Results.
trans-unit.target: If you want to verify the column headings, run the experiment (click RUN below the experiment canvas), click the output port of the Metadata Editor[metadata-editor] module, and select View Results.

trans-unit.source: You can view the output of any module in the same way to view the progress of the data through the experiment.
trans-unit.target: You can view the output of any module in the same way to view the progress of the data through the experiment.

trans-unit.source: The experiment should now look something like this:
trans-unit.target: The experiment should now look something like this:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Adding Metadata Editor</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Adding Metadata Editor</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The next step of the experiment is to generate separate datasets that will be used for training and testing our model.
trans-unit.target: The next step of the experiment is to generate separate datasets that will be used for training and testing our model.

trans-unit.source: To do this, we use the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module.
trans-unit.target: To do this, we use the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module.

trans-unit.source: Find the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module, drag it onto the canvas, and connect it to the last <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> module.
trans-unit.target: Find the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module, drag it onto the canvas, and connect it to the last <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> module.

trans-unit.source: By default, the split ratio is 0.5 and the Randomized split parameter is set.
trans-unit.target: By default, the split ratio is 0.5 and the Randomized split parameter is set.

trans-unit.source: This means that a random half of the data will be output through one port of the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module, and half out the other.
trans-unit.target: This means that a random half of the data will be output through one port of the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module, and half out the other.

trans-unit.source: You can adjust these, as well as the Random seed parameter, to change the split between training and scoring data.
trans-unit.target: You can adjust these, as well as the Random seed parameter, to change the split between training and scoring data.

trans-unit.source: For this example we'll leave them as-is.
trans-unit.target: For this example we'll leave them as-is.

trans-unit.source: The split ratio essentially determines how much of the data is output through the left output port.
trans-unit.target: The split ratio essentially determines how much of the data is output through the left output port.

trans-unit.source: For instance, if you set the ratio to 0.7, then 70% of the data is output through the left port and 30% through the right port.
trans-unit.target: For instance, if you set the ratio to 0.7, then 70% of the data is output through the left port and 30% through the right port.

trans-unit.source: We can use the outputs of the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module however we like, but let's choose to use the left output as training data and the right output as scoring data.
trans-unit.target: We can use the outputs of the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module however we like, but let's choose to use the left output as training data and the right output as scoring data.

trans-unit.source: As mentioned on the UCI website, the cost of misclassifying a high credit risk as low is 5 times larger than the cost of misclassifying a low credit risk as high.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned on the UCI website, the cost of misclassifying a high credit risk as low is 5 times larger than the cost of misclassifying a low credit risk as high.

trans-unit.source: To account for this, we'll generate a new dataset that reflects this cost function.
trans-unit.target: To account for this, we'll generate a new dataset that reflects this cost function.

trans-unit.source: In the new dataset, each high example is replicated 5 times, while each low example is not replicated.
trans-unit.target: In the new dataset, each high example is replicated 5 times, while each low example is not replicated.

trans-unit.source: We can do this replication using R code:
trans-unit.target: We can do this replication using R code:

trans-unit.source: Find and drag the <linkText>Execute R Script[execute-r-script]</linkText><title></title> module onto the experiment canvas and connect the left output port of the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module to the first input port ("Dataset1") of the <linkText>Execute R Script[execute-r-script]</linkText><title></title> module.
trans-unit.target: Find and drag the <linkText>Execute R Script[execute-r-script]</linkText><title></title> module onto the experiment canvas and connect the left output port of the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module to the first input port ("Dataset1") of the <linkText>Execute R Script[execute-r-script]</linkText><title></title> module.

trans-unit.source: In the Properties pane, delete the default text in the R Script parameter and enter this script:
trans-unit.target: In the Properties pane, delete the default text in the R Script parameter and enter this script:

trans-unit.source: We need to do this same replication operation for each output of the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module so that the training and scoring data have the same cost adjustment.
trans-unit.target: We need to do this same replication operation for each output of the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module so that the training and scoring data have the same cost adjustment.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the Execute R Script[execute-r-script] module and select Copy.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the Execute R Script[execute-r-script] module and select Copy.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the experiment canvas and select Paste.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the experiment canvas and select Paste.

trans-unit.source: Connect the first input port of this <linkText>Execute R Script[execute-r-script]</linkText><title></title> module to the right output port of the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the first input port of this <linkText>Execute R Script[execute-r-script]</linkText><title></title> module to the right output port of the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title> module.

trans-unit.source: The copy of the Execute R Script module contains the same script as the original module.
trans-unit.target: The copy of the Execute R Script module contains the same script as the original module.

trans-unit.source: When you copy and paste a module on the canvas, the copy retains all the properties of the original.
trans-unit.target: When you copy and paste a module on the canvas, the copy retains all the properties of the original.

trans-unit.source: Our experiment now looks something like this:
trans-unit.target: Our experiment now looks something like this:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Adding Split module and R scripts</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Adding Split module and R scripts</linkText>

trans-unit.source: For more information on using R scripts in your experiments, see <linkText>Extend your experiment with R</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on using R scripts in your experiments, see <linkText>Extend your experiment with R</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Next: [Train and evaluate the models](machine-learning-walkthrough-4-train-and-evaluate-models.md)
trans-unit.target: Next: [Train and evaluate the models](machine-learning-walkthrough-4-train-and-evaluate-models.md)
